text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for an
album review Cloud Nothings attack on
memory Cloud Nothings is a Cleveland
indie rock band and it's been about a
year since I was first introduced to
this project when it dropped its
sophomore LP which was self-titled on
carpark records and even though I liked
this album a little bit when it first
came out my problem with it ultimately
is that I felt like it was kind of
forgettable which kind of plays out in
the fact that I cannot remember not a
single song from it the album was
chasing after that really lo-fi
washed-out reverb II rock sound that's
that's been big ever since 2008 2009 and
these days you know it's a sound it's a
style that I'm really really just fed up
with I'm just not interested in it you
know I always try to keep my ears open
to whatever is new and whatever's going
on whatever style of music but it's
difficult to stay interested it's
difficult to feel excited when you've
got so many bands lining up to beat the
same exact drum Cloud Nothings did a
huge 180 with this new LP attack on
memory even though that is the title I
think this album is really memorable
this album just brings a set of songs
that are just very clear and muscular
tracks from genres like indie rock and
punk rock and post-hardcore maybe with a
little bit of emo thrown in there
old-school cool ass emo not the emo
everybody's like oh that's emo the I
would just say the strong points of this
LP are catchy hooks strong vocals and
lots of variety in the in the 33 minutes
that this LP lasts and to speak about
the variety of this thing this album
does turn out a few different kinds of
songs and the first kind of song we'll
run into on here especially on tracks 1
& 2 are these these slow burners these
really hard emotional rock songs that
feel just influenced by the repetition
of bands like Slynt but had that fire in
that drive like a Fugazi song the track
like no future no pastures has this riff
and it's being laid on over and over and
each time is just getting it's getting
louder it's getting rougher it's getting
harder as well as the vocals - in the
drums and the second track wasted days
three minutes into the song it just
breaks into the screw that gets jammed
out until the song ends at around the 9
minute mark and this Jam is a real ride
it's fantastic to hear the change that
Cloud Nothings have made on this LP they
are just sounding so much more together
cohesive instrumentally you know what I
mean it sounds like you're really
hearing a band rock the hell out while I
the guitars are getting noisy the vocals
are just losing control but the album is
not just one long drawn-out jam after
another Cloud Nothings throws out some
really fast and catchy songs on here -
but doesn't cheapen the music or or make
it just feel dumbed down in the process
and I think the king of all the songs
that fit that bill is definitely the
tracks stay useless the introduction of
the song sounds like it could have been
written for a strokes tune but the song
kind of morphs into what could have been
like an indie rock song from the 90s but
it doesn't really feel old and nostalgic
the vocals just had this really kind of
strong teenage personality in the hook
just hit so hard I just want to go I
need to stop now bad sometimes the
lyrics are barely intelligible it's clay
yeah you're hearing these growls
sometimes the vocals do come off a
little amateur but they are so emotive
in authentic you know that that cannot
be questioned at least the emotions
behind the vocals they seem really just
angry at some points depressed at other
points anxious there's another track on
this that goes really dark and heavy and
it's the track no sentiment and it's on
that song you get these just wailing
guitars these huge heavy bass riffs and
on here on here I can really tell these
guys are using that Steve Albini
production yes Cloud Nothings actually
worked with Steve Albini
to put this album together I'm sure it
had a lot to do with why the music and
the sound is different on this LP and if
there is one track on here where that is
heavily displayed it's that one and I
like the idea of the song too in the
lyrics it feels like the lyrics are
about being kind of aggressive toward
the past aggressive towards the things
we remember we don't care what you do we
don't care what we'll lose lose in the
process of forgetting in the process of
attacking the past what you're doing
artistically and when you're doing it I
think is a theme that gets played out on
the next track and that's the song our
plan has some really kind of strong
driving guitars and bass on there some
nice keyboard kind of lost in the mix a
little bit and the lyrics go original
it'll never get old essential it'll
never get old I think it kind of pokes
fun of the way we listen to music
consume music like perceive music and
celebrate it how maybe you know and
again this is my interpretation that we
have these albums and these sounds and
and these artists that we you know throw
away their garbage we ignore them oh
that's bad but there are others that we
just kind of treat like sacred cows oh
that's never going to get old the track
cut you as a nice little relationship
song fall in has a female vocal thrown
into the background therefore a nice
little extra sound and the song
separation is a is a nice little
instrumental as well at the end of the
day I feel like this album just kind of
feels like a batch of tracks just an
assembly of random ass songs I didn't
feel any kind of
one strong theme idea or songwriting
style on this thing no real climactic
ending either didn't really blow me away
but this is extremely catchy well
produced well written batch of rock
songs rock songs that I feel like I
could come back to that I want to come
back to that I want to repeat blaring
guitars great interplay between the
musicians memorable hooks it comes off
as really approachable but has this
really badass and aggressive edge to it
to this LP to me is a huge improvement
upon Cloud Nothings previous work I'm
feeling light eight on this thing strong
seven to a light eight if you love rock
